tn.text: This simile speaks of the group as acting as a single person. It refers to a group of who people do everything together in the same way. AT: "as if they were a single man" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
This refers to the land as a whole. AT: "from all the eleven tribes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])
"God and also 400,000 regular soldiers came"
"capable of going to war." They were not going to fight each other.
This word is used here to mark a break in the main storyline. Here the author of the book tells background information about what the people of Benjamin knew.
Mizpah was located high in the mountains.
"for the night" or "to stay for a night"
The word "outrage" describes the "wickedness." AT: "outrageous wickedness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hendiadys]])
This word is used to introduce the conclusion of the speech of the Levite.

tn.ref: give your advice and counsel here
tn.text: The words "advice" and "counsel" refer to the same thing and are repeated for emphasis. They can be combined. AT: "decide what we need to do about this" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
This simile speaks of the group as acting as a single person. They all acted together in exactly the same way. AT: "as if they were a single man" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: None of us will go to his tent ... none of us will return to his house
tn.text: These two clauses say basically the same thing twice for emphasis. They can be combined. The words "none ... go" and "none ... return" emphasizes how the people will continue to stay there. They can be stated in positive form. AT: "We will all stay here" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
These words introduce the main portion of what the people say after the initial exclamation.
This involved tossing or rolling small marked stones to determine what God wants.

tn.ref: ten men of a hundred ... one hundred of a thousand ... one thousand of ten thousand
tn.text: "10 men out of 100 ... 100 out of 1,000 ... 1,000 out of 10,000" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
"food" or "supplies"
"came together to attack the city"
This is an idiom. AT: "kill them" or "execute them" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here "voice" refers to the message that they spoke. AT: "what their brother said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
six thousand** - "26,000" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
"700" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
handed** - A left-handed person is someone who is more skilled with their left hand than with their right hand.

tn.ref: could sling a stone at a hair and not miss
tn.text: This show how amazingly well they could aim and hit their target. It can be stated in positive form. AT: "could throw a stone at even a hair and hit it" or "could throw a stone at something as small as a hair and hit it"
"not including"
"asked God what to do" or "asked God how to continue"

There is some question about the meaning of the Hebrew text. Instead of meaning that they set up their camp near Gibeah, it could mean that the army went out and stood across from Gibeah ready to fight.
two thousand** - "22,000" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
Here "strengthened" is an idiom that means they encouraged each other. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This probably means that the Israelites prepared their battle lines for the next day's fighting. AT: "they got ready to fight the next day" (UDB)
The method they used is not stated. The priest may have cast lots to determine God's will.
"18,000" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
"in Yahweh's presence" or "to Yahweh"

tn.ref: for the ark of the covenant of God ... was serving before the ark in those days
tn.text: This is background information that the author inserted to help the reader understand how the people asked Yahweh for an answer. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
"was at Bethel in those days"
The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. AT: "was serving as priest before the ark" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. AT: "Attack the army of Benjamin" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "Israel" refers to the people of Israel. AT: "the Israelites" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"in ambush"
The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. AT: "fought against the people of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: they were drawn away from the city
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "the people of Israel drew them away from the city" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: They began to kill some of the people
tn.text: The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. AT: "The people of Benjamin began to kill some of the men of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"just as before" or "just like the first two times"
This is the name of a city. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of a place. Other translations may read "fields of Gibeah" or "west of Gibeah" or "Maareh Geba." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"10,000"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
This is an idiom that means these were particularly good soldiers. AT: "well-trained soldier" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here immanent disaster is spoken of as if it was standing very close by them. AT: "they would soon be completely defeated" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: The men of Israel had given ground to Benjamin, because they were counting on the men ... outside Gibeah
tn.text: From this sentence until the end of verse 41 is background information that the writer inserted to explain to the readers how the ambush defeated the Benjamites. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
This is an idiom that means they intentionally retreated. AT: "had allowed Benjamin to move forward" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: they were counting on the men
tn.text: This is an idiom that means they trusted their men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This verse continues to give background information that the writer inserted to explain to the readers how the ambush defeated the Benjamites. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
"would retreat from the fight"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "we have defeated them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This verse continues to give background information that the writer inserted to explain to the readers how the ambush defeated the Benjamites. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
"great harm" or "trouble" or "misery"
This idiom means it happened to them. AT: "happened to them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This speaks about fighting as if it were a person who could overtake someone. AT: "But the soldiers of Israel caught up to them" or "But they were not able to escape the fighting" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
This is the name of a place. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
The completed destruction of the Benjamites is spoken of as if the Israelites stomped on their bodies. AT: "they completely destroyed them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"18,000" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
"had fought bravely in the battle"
"The remaining Benjamites turned and fled"
"5,000 ... 2,000" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
This is the name of a place. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
five thousand** - "25,000" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
"600" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: turned back against the people of Benjamin
tn.text: These people of Benjamin are not the soldiers who fled to the rock of Rimmon, but the ones who were still in the city.
Here "the ... city" refers to the people in that city. AT: "everyone who was in the city" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This idiom refers to everything that they found as they went toward the city. AT: "they came to" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
